alert.note: Alert for Clark; Cowlitz (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Portland (Northwest Oregon and Southwest Washington)
info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued June 11 at 4:32AM PDT by NWS Portland
info.description: ...High flows on the Columbia River through at least the middle of next week... ...A series of wet storm systems will result in rising rivers across the Pacific Northwest over the next several days. As this water feeds into the Columbia River, expect the Columbia River to approach minor flood stage between Vancouver and Kelso late in the weekend into early next week. The last time the Columbia River hit minor flood stage was in the Spring of 2017. It also came a few inches away in the Spring of 2019. At this point, the Columbia River is forecast to fall short of minor flood stage, but given unforeseen dam releases upstream can happen, there remains some uncertainty in river levels over the coming week. Either way, the impacts will be similar for most recreational users. Those venturing in the river should be prepared for cold water and unusually powerful currents. Boaters should be aware that many objects typically exposed along the sides of the river channel will now be below the water`s surface and could damage their boat. A few paths along the river`s edge may also become submerged. Residents impacted by the waters levels in the Spring of 2017 should take precautions to protect their property as well as continuing to monitor the latest forecast. Finally, Interstate 5 bridge lifts are more frequent during periods of high flows on the Columbia River.
